quote0.quote: I've always been interested in people, but I've never liked them.
quote0.author: W. Somerset Maugham

quote1.quote: If there is a look of human eyes that tells of perpetual loneliness, so there is also the familiar look that is the sign of perpetual crowds.
quote1.author: Alice Meynell

quote2.quote: The south produced statesmen and soldiers, planters and doctors and lawyers and poets, but certainly no engineers and mechanics. Let Yankees adopt such low callings. Gone With The Wind
quote2.author: Margaret Mitchell

quote3.quote: He is one of those people who would be enormously improved by death.
quote3.author: Hector Hugh Munro

quote4.quote: He was a sociologist; he had got into an intellectual muddle early on in life and never managed to get out.
quote4.author: Iris Murdoch

quote5.quote: People are all exactly alike. There's no such thing as a race and barely such a thing as an ethnic group. If we were dogs, we'd be the same breed. George Bush and an Australian Aborigine have fewer differences than a Lhasa apso and a toy fox terrier. A Japanese raised in Riyadh would be an Arab. A Zulu raised in New Rochelle would be an orthodontist. People are all the same, though their circumstances differ terribly.
quote5.author: P. J. O'RourkeHolidays in Hell, "Atlantic Monthly Press"

quote6.quote: 'Exactly,' he said, while he leant forward excitedly, for all the world like a Jack-in-the-box let loose. 'Precisely; and you are a journalist - call yourself one, at least - and it should be part of your business to notice and describe people. I don't mean only the wonderful personage with the clear Saxon features, the fine blue eyes, the noble brow and classic face, but the ordinary person - the person who represents ninety out of every hundred of his own kind - the average Englishman, say, of the middle classes, who is neither very tall nor very short, who wears a moustache which is neither fair nor dark, but which masks his mouth, and a top hat which hides the shape of his head and brow, a man, in fact, who dresses like hundreds of his fellow-creatures, moves like them, speaks like them, has no peculiarity.'
quote6.author: Baroness Emmuska Orczyfrom 'The Mysterious Death on the Underground Railway'

quote7.quote: When you have a taste for exceptional people, you always end up meeting them everywhere.
quote7.author: Mac Orlan

quote8.quote: Towns are full of people, houses full of tenants, hotels full of guests, trains full of travelers, caf?s full of customers, parks full of promenaders, consulting-rooms of famous doctors full of patients, theatres full of spectators, and beaches full of bathers. What previously was, in general, no problem, now begins to be an everyday one, namely, to find room.
quote8.author: Jos

quote9.quote: That you may please others you must be forgetful of yourself.
quote9.author: Ovid

quote10.quote: All I say is, nobody has any business to go around looking like a horse and behaving as if it were all right. You don't catch horses going around looking like people, do you?
quote10.author: Dorothy ParkerHorsie

quote11.quote: There are only three types of people; those who have found God and serve him; those who have not found God and seek him, and those who live not seeking, or finding him. The first are rational and happy; the second unhappy and rational, and the third foolish and unhappy.
quote11.author: Blaise Pascal

quote12.quote: Most of the great triumphs and tragedies of history are caused not by people being fundamentally good or fundamentally evil, but by people being fundamentally people.
quote12.author: Terry Pratchett

quote13.quote: A person well satisfied with themselves is seldom satisfied with others, and others, rarely are with them.
quote13.author: Francois de la Rochefoucauld

quote14.quote: There are people who in spite of their merit disgust us, and others who please us in spite of their faults.
quote14.author: Francois de la Rochefoucauld

quote15.quote: People are eternally divided into two classes, the believer, builder, and praiser, and the unbeliever, destroyer and critic.
quote15.author: John Ruskin

quote16.quote: People have the power to redeem the work of fools.
quote16.author: Patty Smith

quote17.quote: Unhurt people are not much good in the world.
quote17.author: Enid Starkie

quote18.quote: There used to be a thing or a commodity we put great store by. It was called the People. Find out where the People have gone. I don't mean the square-eyed toothpaste-and-hair-dye people or the new-car-or-bust people, or the success-and-coronary people. Maybe they never existed, but if there ever were the People, that's the commodity the Declaration was talking about, and Mr. Lincoln.
quote18.author: John Steinbeck

quote19.quote: Men often treat others worse than they treat themselves, but they rarely treat anyone better. It is the height of folly to expect consideration and decency from a person who mistreats himself.
quote19.author: Thomas Szasz

quote20.quote: You know about a person who deeply interests you more than you can be told. A look, a gesture, an act, which to everybody else is insignificant tells you more about that one than words can.
quote20.author: Henry David Thoreau

quote21.quote: He who knows others is wise.He who knows himself is enlightened.
quote21.author: Lao TzuTao Te Ching

quote22.quote: We are the people our parents warned us about.
quote22.author: Source Unknown

quote23.quote: There are two kinds of people; those who can count and those who can't.
quote23.author: Source Unknown

quote24.quote: People will teach you how to sell them if you'll pay attention to the messages they send you.
quote24.author: Source Unknown

quote25.quote: The crowd gives the leader new strength
quote25.author: Evenus

quote26.quote: The time comes when each one of us has to give up as illusions the expectations which, in his youth, he pinned upon his fellow-men, and when he may learn how much difficulty and pain has been added to his life by their ill-will.
quote26.author: Sigmund Freud

quote27.quote: The person you consider ignorant and insignificant is the one who came from God, that he might learn bliss from grief and knowledge from gloom.
quote27.author: Kahlil Gibran, "The Visit of Wisdom"

quote28.quote: Only when human sorrows are turned into a toy with glaring colors will baby people become interested -- for a while at least. The people are a very fickle baby that must have new toys every day.
quote28.author: Emma Goldman

quote29.quote: Every thought, action, decision or feeling creates an eddy in the interlocking, interbalancing, ever-moving energy fields of life, leaving a permanent record for all of time. This realization can be intimidating when it first dawns on us, but it becomes a springboard for rapid evolution.
quote29.author: David R. Hawkins

quote30.quote: No matter where or what, there are makers, takers, and fakers.
quote30.author: Robert A. Heinlein

quote31.quote: The only thing that could spoil a day was people. People were always the limiters of happiness except for the very few that were as good as spring itself.
quote31.author: Ernest Hemingway

quote32.quote: Sad people dislike the happy, and the happy the sad; the quick thinking the sedate, and the careless the busy and industrious.
quote32.author: Horace

quote33.quote: I hate the irreverent rabble and keep them far from me.
quote33.author: Horace

quote34.quote: Some people can stay longer in an hour than others can in a week.
quote34.author: William Dean Howells

quote35.quote: The person who can be only serious or only cheerful, is but half a man.
quote35.author: Leigh Hunt

quote36.quote: We demand that people should be true to the pictures we have of them, no matter how repulsive those pictures may be: we prefer the true portrait in all its homogeneity, to one with a detail added which refuses to fit in.
quote36.author: Pamela Hansford Johnson

quote37.quote: The people long eagerly for just two things. Bread and circuses.
quote37.author: Juvenal

quote38.quote: If you cannot mould yourself as you would wish, how can you expect other people to be entirely to your liking?
quote38.author: Thomas KempisThe Imitation of Christ, I

quote39.quote: We hold the view that the people make the best judgment in the long run.
quote39.author: John Fitzgerald Kennedy

quote40.quote: Spiritual superiority only sees the individual. But alas, ordinarily we human beings are sensual and, therefore, as soon as it is a gathering, the impression changes -- we see something abstract, the crowd, and we become different. But in the eyes of God, the infinite spirit, all the millions that have lived and now live do not make a crowd, He only sees each individual.
quote40.author: Soren Kierkegaard

quote41.quote: All the people like us are We, and everyone else is They.
quote41.author: Rudyard Kipling

quote42.quote: One can no longer live with people: it is too hideous and nauseating. Owners and owned, they are like the two sides of a ghastly disease.
quote42.author: D. H. (David Herbert) Lawrence

quote43.quote: Crowds are somewhat like the sphinx of ancient fable: It is necessary to arrive at a solution of the problems offered by their psychology or to resign ourselves to being devoured by them.
quote43.author: Gustave Le Bon

quote44.quote: In New York, people are very overbooked.You say, When do you want to have dinner? It's May. They say, What about October? And then they complain: Oh you can't believe how booked up I am.
quote44.author: Fran Lebowitz

quote45.quote: In each of us there is a little of all of us.
quote45.author: G. C. (Georg Christoph) Lichtenberg

quote46.quote: I am convinced we do not only love ourselves in others but hate ourselves in others too.
quote46.author: G. C. (Georg Christoph) Lichtenberg

quote47.quote: If all power is in the people, if there is no higher law than their will, and if by counting their votes, their will may be ascertained -- then the people may entrust all their power to anyone, and the power of the pretender and the usurper is then legitimate. It is not to be challenged since it came originally from the sovereign people.
quote47.author: Walter Lippmann

quote48.quote: Social movements are at once the symptoms and the instruments of progress. Ignore them and statesmanship is irrelevant; fail to use them and it is weak.
quote48.author: Walter Lippmann

quote49.quote: Please accept my resignation. I don't care to belong to any club that will have me as a member.
quote49.author: Groucho Marx

quote50.quote: Some people are electrifying, they light up a room when they leave.
quote50.author: Yiddish Proverb

quote51.quote: Everyone is kneaded out of the same dough but not baked in the same oven.
quote51.author: Yiddish Proverb

quote52.quote: There are three kinds of people; those that make things happen, those that watch things happen and those who don't know what's happening.
quote52.author: Proverb

quote53.quote: The man who follows the crowd will usually get no further than the crowd. The man who walks alone is likely to find himself in places no one has
quote53.author: Alan Ashley-Pitt

quote54.quote: To understand the true quality of people, you must look into their minds, and examine their pursuits and aversions.
quote54.author: Marcus Aurelius

quote55.quote: There are two kinds of people in the world, those who believe there are two kinds of people in the world and those who don't.
quote55.author: Robert Benchley

quote56.quote: Just when you think that a person is just a backdrop for the rest of the universe, watch them and see that they laugh, they cry, they tell jokes ... they're just friends waiting to be made.
quote56.author: Dr. Jeffrey Borenstein

quote57.quote: What's important is promising something to the people, not actually keeping those promises. The people have always lived on hope alone.
quote57.author: Hermann Broch

quote58.quote: The ones who count are those persons who
quote58.author: Martin Buber

quote59.quote: If the people are happy, united, wealthy, and powerful, we presume the rest. We conclude that to be good from whence good is derived.
quote59.author: Edmund Burke

quote60.quote: There are two kinds of people, those who finish what they start and so on.
quote60.author: Robert Byrne

quote61.quote: Look, when that crowd gets to cheering, when we know they're with us, when we know they like us, we play better. A hell of a lot better!
quote61.author: Bill Carlin

quote62.quote: But we are the people of England; and we have not spoken yet. Smile at us, pay us, pass us. But do not quite forget.
quote62.author: G. K. Chesterton

quote63.quote: If it has to choose who is to be crucified, the crowd will always save Barabbas.
quote63.author: Jean Cocteau

quote64.quote: There are two types of people. Those we who come into a room and say, Well, here I am! and those who come in and say, Ah, there you are.
quote64.author: Frederick L. Collins

quote65.quote: Always remember, there are two types of people in this world. Those who come into a room and say, Well, here I am! and those who come in and say, Ah, there you are!
quote65.author: Frederick L. Collins

quote66.quote: These people have no religion, neither are they idolaters, but are a very gentle race, without the knowledge of any iniquity; they neither kill, nor steal, nor carry weapons... they have a knowledge that there is a God above, and are firmly persuaded that we have come from heaven.
quote66.author: Christopher ColumbusJournal of the First Voyage to America. (1492-1493)

quote67.quote: A man's real life is that accorded to him in the thoughts of other men by reason of respect or natural love.
quote67.author: Joseph Conrad

quote68.quote: It is when we try to grapple with another man's intimate need that we perceive how incomprehensible, wavering, and misty are the beings that share with us the sight of the stars and the warmth of the sun.
quote68.author: Joseph Conrad

quote69.quote: We have no higher life that is really apart from other people. It is by imagining them that our personality is built up; to be without the power of imagining them is to be a low-grade idiot.
quote69.author: Charles Horton Cooley

quote70.quote: If one had to worry about one's actions in respect of other people's ideas, one might as well be buried alive in an antheap or married to an ambitious violinist. Whether that man is the prime minister, modifying his opinions to catch votes, or a bourgeois in terror lest some harmless act should be misunderstood and outrage some petty convention, that man is an inferior man and I do not want to have anything to do with him any more than I want to eat canned salmon.
quote70.author: Aleister Crowley

quote71.quote: Only a few human beings should grow to the square mile; they are commonly planted too close.
quote71.author: William T. Davis

quote72.quote: What we know of other people's only our memory of the moments during which we knew them.
quote72.author: TS (Thomas Stearns) Eliot

quote73.quote: The people are to be taken in small doses.
quote73.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quote74.quote: Other men are lenses through which we read our own minds. Each man seeks those of different quality from his own, and such as are good of their kind; that is, he seeks other men, and the rest.
quote74.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quote75.quote: The toughest part of getting to the top of the ladder, is getting through the crowd at the bottom.
quote75.author: Source Unknown

quote76.quote: There are two kinds of people in the world. Those who walk into a room and say, There you are and those who say, Here I am
quote76.author: Abigail Van Buren

quote77.quote: The public is a ferocious beast. One must either chain it up or flee from it.
quote77.author: Voltaire (François-Marie Arouet)

quote78.quote: We are all what we pretend to be, but, we had better be very careful what we pretend.
quote78.author: Kurt Vonnegut

quote79.quote: I am a deeply superficial person.
quote79.author: Andy Warhol

quote80.quote: No sociologist should think himself too good, even in his old age, to make tens of thousands of quite trivial computations in his head and perhaps for months at a time. One cannot with impunity try to transfer this task entirely to mechanical assistants if one wishes to figure something, even though the final result is often small indeed.
quote80.author: Max Weber

quote81.quote: I wonder if we are all wrong about each other, if we are just composing unwritten novels about the people we meet?
quote81.author: Rebecca West

quote82.quote: The genius of the United States is not best or most in its executives or legislatures, nor in its ambassadors or authors or colleges, or churches, or parlors, nor even in its newspapers or inventors, but always most in the common people.
quote82.author: Walt Whitman

quote83.quote: It is absurd to divide people into good and bad. People are either charming or tedious.
quote83.author: Oscar Wilde

quote84.quote: The eyes of others our prisons; their thoughts our cages.
quote84.author: Virginia Woolf

quote85.quote: Great bodies of people are never responsible for what they do.
quote85.author: Virginia Woolf

quote86.quote: The only certainty about following the crowd is that you will all get there together.
quote86.author: Mychal Wynn

quote87.quote: The people, and the people alone, are the motive force in the making of world history.
quote87.author: Mao Zedong
